title: What will be Uber's end-of-day market capitalization on the day of its initial public offering?
possible_answers: More than $70 billion but less than $100 billion
Uber will not have an IPO before 1 October 2019
preds: Bloomberg is saying market cap is $69.711B now [1]. Not sure if this will be the final closing price. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/UBER:US

Oh well. Lesson: reporting on the expected valuation was somewhat inaccurate. NYT and CNBC quoted valuations in the $80-90B range all the way into the IPO, but those figures were their own calculations that multiplied a given share price by all shares (so called diluted method). In reality not all shares that could have been sold were sold, leading to a much lower actual valuation. As I've encountered before, news media will often simplify (or over-simplify depending on your perspective) technical details like this and it's important to question their calculations.

Per Bloomberg, 'Shares of the ride-hailing giant closed at $41.57, well under their IPO price of $45, for a market capitalization of $69.7 billion.' https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-05-10/uber-drops-after-raising-8-1-billion-in-biggest-ipo-of-2019
Adjusting for given IPO pricing & pre-market delta. Gives an estimated end of day market cap of $80.73B (+/- $9.64B) & an 84% confidence interval of $70B-$100B

Reducing probability of a spike in price near the close given intra-day trading so far below IPO price. At current levels ($43.75) still in $70-100 billion range. Unlikely to go below $70 billion, given the intra-day trading range--would need to drop below $39/share.

BBG is reporting a lower cap than the numbers reported previously by CNBC, NYT (which calculated total cap on a diluted basis). To watch: will the 27 million optional shares be purchased by underwriters? [1] That will help determine the total number of shares bought and thus the market cap. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/09/uber-ipo-pricing.html
Uber opened at $42, implying a valuation of 77. Only a 9% drop is needed to take it below $70 bill valuation.

Let see: Lyft lost 26 percent after it's IPO.  The price seems to have already been lowered to account for the post-IPO decline in Lyft.   You would expect a lower IPO price to be followed by a larger bounce on the first day of trading.  The drivers went on a short-term 2- to 24-hour  strike (depending on driver) this week for a living wage--some are not even making minimum wage.   Thus, drivers could unionize, new laws could make them employees, etc.  I am sure investors are sure there is a good chance Uber's labor costs will increase.  Uber's gross revenue has gone from $3.5 billion to $9.2 billion in two years.  Currently it has EBITDA of -$1.8 billion and net income of $997 million.   The yield curve went inverted this week.  A lot of people watch this indicator these days, including potential investors.  The DOW, S&P and Nasdaq all declined this week due to Trump's Chinese tariff threat.  This adds some volatility.  If the stock-buying public decides the threat is over-stated, the IPO price could get a Friday bump in a rising market.  If the stock-buying public decides otherwise, the IPO price could decline.  Often, there is a initial spike in the price followed a fall back to earth.  Thus, the time of  day that the stock is put in circulation could also make a difference.   The real issue is right now how much volatility is in the stock.   It will be offered at $82.5 billion.  I tried to find first day trading ranges for a number of dot.com IPOs but ran out of time.   82.5 is 17.5 less than 100 and 12.5 greater than 70.  Thus, a 21 % increase would be needed to push it to the next higher bracket but only a %15 decrease is needed to drop it into the next lower bracket.  The value of the stock was lowered to bottom part of the IPO offer range.  Hence, the lowered price already accounts for some of the downside risk but also indicates a loss of confidence by the underwriter.  On balance, I think there is little chance of a greater than 100 valuation at the end of the day.  However, there is a chance of a decrease to less than 70.

Confirmed offer price at $45, implying a valuation of 82.4 https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/09/uber-ipo-pricing.html Given historical base rates discussed in my earlier post, a jump to a close high enough to push the valuation beyond $100 billion is relatively unlikely. Also: the stock market is having a rough few days. This might make it even harder.
Latest pricing comes in at low end of range, $45/share, an $82B marketcap. ±15% gives us a closing range of $70-94B tomorrow. Good luck!

Adjusting slightly based on expected listing tomorrow, May 10 at a price of $45/share for an implied market cap of $82.4 billion. Depending on trading activity, closing price could be higher (or lower), but I expect there will be some upward movement given pricing at the somewhat lower end of the range. It may also get a pop if investors think we are heading toward recession, given recent yield curve inversion, in the hopes of making a quick profit. The price would have to increase over 20% to exceed the $100 million mark, so I'm still only giving that a 25% chance. https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/09/uber-ipo-pricing.html

The talk about this deal has become 100% weak.  Pricing at the low end of the range, only 5x oversubscribed instead of 10x, pricing in a weak market...$100 billion + is now off the table. Morgan Stanley is going to have its hands full just to stabilize the price, and that stabilization is the only reason why I am closing the door on $70 billion or below.

Consensus seems to price IPO around $90b. Of course possible it will rise/decline opening day and end up higher/lower. With recent market trends and fact Uber has yet to make $, thinking people will exercise caution. But a 15% bump would take them over $100b. https://www.thestreet.com/markets/5-things-you-must-know-before-the-market-opens-thursday-14952431

Price is still targeted at an overall valuation of between $80 and $90 billion ($86 as reported by NYT [1]). This is not yet the official Uber offer price, so there is uncertainty with regard to the actual number. If the valuation based on the offer price is indeed around $86 then my base rate analysis [2] suggests a closing price above $100 is quite unlikely. To watch: "The company is still taking investor orders for its stock and plans to finalize a price by the end of Thursday." per NY Times:
Uber plans to price its initial public offering at the midpoint of its expected price range. At the midpoint, $47 a share, Uber would be valued at about $86 billion.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-ipo-strike/eyeing-ipo-riches-uber-drivers-go-on-strike-in-uk-ahead-of-u-s-action-idUSKCN1SE0A5
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-ipo-india-drivers/as-uber-gears-up-for-ipo-many-indian-drivers-talk-of-shattered-dreams-idUSKCN1SE0OP On one hand, there is the prospect that negative press about how Uber treats its drivers will cause investors to shy away.  On the other hand, lots of investors think a company is just swell if it cheats, shortchanges, or otherwise oppresses its  providers or workers or whatever they're called, on the premise that this means higher profits for the investors.   One counts more heavily on the latter in guessing that such coverage will not any further impede Uber's ambitions.  (Full disclosure:  I am very often wrong in such matters--not, I think, owing to the altruism of investors, but rather to misjudging the magnitudes of the various effects.)

There's been a significant amount of negative PR about Uber in recent days;  Uber drivers are striking today. When this IPO was first announced, the estimated valuation was $120B for Uber.  Then Lyft went public, after which its shares have lost 26%.  I notice how often the fall in the Lyft share price is mentioned in articles about Uber.  I also notice how, over time, the estimated valuation of Uber has fallen from $120B, to $100-120B, to $90-100B, and now I most commonly read "as much as $90B".   Decreasing my forecast for $100-130B.

It's hard to see how Uber will ever make a noticeable profit.  Not sure how network effects work in a relatively unregulated and highly competitive business like ride-hailing, which has virtually zero barriers to entry and switching costs for both drivers and passengers.   First-mover advantage probably doesn't work either, or we'd be doing this on Netscape.  First-mover disadvantages include for example bearing the legal costs of fighting the employment status of drivers and unfriendly regulations, as well as the cost of ironing out software and other logistics issues, while competitors just sit back and wait for a result. Their future plans for more automation and whatnot are at best problematic, and not necessarily profitable either. There are of course True Believers, as the continuing Muskathon demonstrates, as well as large pots of money available to large corporations and private funders, who are presumably betting not just on Uber but also on its competitors.   Full disclosure:  It is possible that I have no idea what I am talking about.  This happens increasingly often, especially in matters related to any technology more advanced than carving things on stones and flinging them over to the next cave.

I am therefore tacking closer to the Outside View base rates I discussed above. [1] https://www.wsj.com/articles/uber-proposals-value-company-at-120-billion-in-a-possible-ipo-1539690343

Joining the fray a bit late but I do it because it seems I can add value relative to the crowd (and because I now have the time). Summary: from today's announced Uber offer price, the stock would have to rise ~18% to breach $100 bill. valuation. That seems less than 50% likely from historical base rate data but a number of Inside View factors suggest that's an underestimate. ~~~
Base rate:
~~~ IPOs are notoriously hard to analyze because of lack of data. So I look at how past IPOs performed on the first day of trading. This paper estimated first day returns (between closing price and offer price) from a sample of 1,887 US IPOs [1] (caveat - sample contains many stocks from the internet bubble). Median first-day return was 13%, mean 35% (distribution skewed to the right) with SD of 65%.  Raises the question: what is Uber's offer price going to be? From today: "Uber plans to offer its shares to investors for $44 to $50 each, putting its total valuation between $80 billion and $90 billion" [4].  If we assume an $85 bill. valuation implied by the offer price, the share price would have to rise 18% on the first trading day to breach $100 bill. valuation. The data above suggests that happens in less than half the cases. I have to wrap this up now but will estimate the percentage in the next post. Other data confirms top-level finding above: 
-This paper [1] features data from 311 IPOs between 1996 and 1997. It estimates first-day return. The median is 5.9% (25th percentile is 0 and 75th percentile is 17.5). Suggesting a lower likelihood of >18% returns (25%)
-This paper [6] with ~200 IPOs estimated a median first-day return of 4% and an SD of 5.6% ~~~
Inside view:
~~~ Three factors point to a higher possible first day performance.
-Uber Is trying to avoid what happened to Lyft and is therefore likely pricing its offer price conservatively suggesting a bigger potential rise than expected by the historical data.
-Uber Is making sure the lock-up provisions in its IPO will keep employees and other early holders from dumping [5]
-Paypal is buying in to Uber with $0.5 bill, which could encourage others to have more confidence in the stock [6, 3] Other:
-unknown unknowns: factors I haven't yet considered. To watch:
-Uber's road show will give some indication of how much positive or negative sentiment there is around the IPO.
-Any news on Uber's offer price. [1] https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304405X13000603
[2] http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.524.122&rep=rep1&type=pdf
[3] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/04/26/reuters-america-uber--sale-of-shares-to-paypal-will-not-be-registered-in-ipo-will-be-subject-to-a-lockup-agreement-with-underwriters-for-a.html
[4] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/25/technology/uber-ipo-price-valuation.html?dlbk=&emc=edit_dk_20190426&nl=dealbook&nlid=0_dk_20190426&te=1
[5] https://www.ft.com/content/0bb7f96c-5ba9-11e9-9dde-7aedca0a081a
[6] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/26/business/dealbook/uber-ipo.html Curious if fellow forecasters have any feedback @pietrokc @Anneinak @dsarin @michalbod @Hammer-Time @MaRott @shivadiva @Resonancia @cmeinel

Uber is shooting for a high point of about $100B according to Business Insider and other media sources. This is an optimistic figure from media speculation, and even if they are oversubscribed, they may face activities of certain investors like the ones in facebook's IPO, when the shares were sold en masse to lower the price then repurchased at the lower price point. Therefore, I think the likelihood that it will be $40-$100 is the highest probability, with the lower side being more likely. The other 15% over $100B is a short term prediction, as I think even if they do close that high, their shares will drop significantly over the next few days.

However, valuation does not equal end-of-day market cap, which will depend on both opening price as well as investor interest on the first day of trading. If opening price is anywhere near $100 billion, the closing price could exceed the $100 billion mark. Thursday's financial performance should shed additional light.

Going out on a limp here, but given Lyft's recent IPO I'm making the following base assumptions...
1) Lyft opened at ~38% higher than any reasonable assessment of their value, Uber will likely follow suit (SD 1/2 the delta, so 19%)
2) Lyft trended downward all day and closed down ~11%, Uber will likely do the same (same metric for SD, so 5.5%)
3) Uber's valuation prior to their IPO will remain within 5% of it's current value 
4) Uber's valuation itself... I'll baseline with  CrunchBase's estimate, derived from Lyft's metric of 9.1 x Net Revenue gives $109.9 billion... Holy *@#$ let's make this more reasonable... As they point out Lyft grew by 100% in 2018, Uber by "only" 43%, so let's assume 57% of the delta between their known value a year ago ($72 billion) gives an estimate of $93.6 billion With a little bit of plug & chug this gives...
 - Opening valuation: $129 billion (+/- $18 billion)
 - Closing valuation: $116 billion (+/- $32 billion) & subsequently the above distribution (plus 1% for them not IPO-ing in 2019) Broke things down numbers wise a bit more clearly here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1rHBQGfX9rO79HrcQ7tSw-mVRkq7aC5RlULo53fOUEV8/edit?usp=sharing
Based on the Lyft market cap of $22.2B and comparison of the two companies (Revenue, Bookings, Margin).

Prior to its IPO today, Lyft had an estimated private valuation of $11 billion. At the end of the first day of trading, it had a market capitalization according to Bloomberg of $22.4 billion, or roughly double its valuation as a private company, calculated as 273.1 million shares out x $78.28 per share.  Some estimates place Uber's valuation at $70 billion as a private company. Its investment bankers think the market cap could be north of $120 billion. Judging by the valuation uplift cause by Lyft's IPO, that doesn't seem far fetched.  Unless the stock market declines 10% or more between now and the IPO, which seems unlikely to me, I think the range for UBER (just guessing that will be the ticker symbol-- call me crazy) is $110 billion to $140 billion with a 70-80% probability given today's evidence, the solid economy, and moderating interest rates lending support to the stock market.

February update - staying put until I see movement. Some thoughts below. "Khosrowshahi appears to be on track to keep his word about taking Uber public within 18 to 36 months of joining the company in August 2017."[1] Taking Mr. K at his word, this window is open from now until August 2020. Using an 18-month time frame and assuming an even probability distribution, that is about 100% / 18 months = ~5.5% per month with the probability accumulating cumulatively for each month they don't list. This means that by the closing date of the question the probability of Uber listing is ~ 44%. However, I think the chance of this happening sooner rather than later skews the base calculation. "Washington hijinks are unlikely to derail the ride-hailing giants’ march toward IPO. That’s partly because [Uber and Lyft] need a steady stream of investor cash to keep operating. If they didn’t list, they would probably need to tap the private markets again. Another key reason for Uber is that, when it raised money from SoftBank last year, the company agreed to free up some shareholders to sell on the private markets if it didn’t go public in 2019. That’s a situation the startup probably wants to avoid. And finally, the jockeying between Uber and Lyft only ups the competitive pressure for each to list before the other sucks up all the oxygen and investor money.[2] Right now, my probabilities are 67% for a listing / 33% against by the closing date of this question. I can't really justify any adjustments at the moment. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-02-01/uber-s-drive-to-clean-up-its-act-en-route-to-an-ipo-quicktake
[2] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-11/companies-to-watch-in-ipo-land-this-year

according to the article  ...

The wild card is the specification that we are to forecast the *end-of-day* valuation.  A well-run roadshow could see a large run-up in the share price on the day of the IPO.  It could see a lift of 20%, 30% or more at market close, on top of pricing at the high end of the range.  A poorly run IPO could see a fall in the price.   Manhattan Venture Partners, an IPO research firm, assigns a fair market value of $52 billion to Uber, partly based on its 17.5% equity stake in Chinese ride sharing-service Didi Chuxing.  https://mvp.vc/researched-company/uber-pre-ipo-research-report/ Toyota's investment in Uber valued the company at $72 billion, and an earlier round valued it at $62 billion.  So anything above $80 billion would leave those investors not unhappy.  The bankers reportedly envision a $120 billion valuation.   As I mentioned, a well-run roadshow could see the IPO price there and run up to $150 billion or $160 billion or higher.  Some consideration should be given to that possibility.   On the other hand.... It's two days before Christmas 2018.  The market has declined 18 percent from its high and is poised on the precipice of a bear market.  No one knows whether a recession has arrived much sooner than anyone expected.  The bankers would be fully justified in going out with a valuation today of 20% less, or $96 billion.  By the time the IPO occurs, the market could be even lower, and a poorly run IPO could lead to a Manhattan Venture Partners-type valuation of $52 billion, with the end-of-day wildcard taking it below $40 billion.  This is a fascinating question because the range is so extreme.  I currently think the only course is to spread my bets, with a tilt in the direction of making the current investors and management satisfied, which would occur at a bottom of $80 billion.

approx growth for 2 years	30%

daily revenue per day in 2019	$107,250,000

Estimates for IPO price range from $70-120 billion. The question asks what the market cap will be at end of trading. I therefore took into account both opening price and first-day trading activity. Since this is the most anticipated IPO of 2019, it's going to have a lot of investor interest and likely will open above the IPO price and will trade on huge volumes the first day. Best Nasdaq IPO 1-day performers in 2018 averaged close to 100% above IPO price. I suspect  the underwriters will want to be a little conservative so that some investors ca take first day profits on the hype. In addition, we should see lots of volume early on as investors try to get in, driving up the 1st day price. While a 100% increase over IPO prices seems unlikely, some of the best tech performers of 2018 saw 33% 1-day returns and they were no where near the hype Uber is getting. If the underwriters price the stock at $100 billion, it doesn't seem unreasonable for 1st-day close to be at 50% above that ($150 billion). I'm not talking about sustainable prices, I'm just talking about 1st day hype and valuation at the close. Given the current uncertainties in the overall market and signs of softening, investors might see it as a particularly appetizing IPO (irrational but not unexpected) and drive price up. This seems the most likely scenario. Given the broad valuation range, I'll stick with $100 billion for now and assume a 50% pop as most likely (60%), with 35% at $100-$130, assuming a more tepid response. There is a possibility that investors won't like Uber's performance to date and, if the market sags substantially, they could decide to wait, but given the hype I see this is only a slightly non-trivial probability (5%).

Uber, as a company, does not make sense from a financial perspective. Hubert Horan has posted an excellent analysis of the firm here: http://horanaviation.com/Uber.html The bottom line is that Uber continues to highly subsidize rides for users, using investor funds. There are few economies of scale to leverage by expanding the user base (which is a large part of the reason why the taxi industry has not consolidated) and there are next to no network effects to take advantage of as is the case with social media platforms. The only way their valuation makes sense is if you believe they will become THE dominant player in the autonomous driving space, which will be challenging given the number of competitors currently rushing to market and the fact that the product itself appears years away. In addition, becoming an autonomous car platform would significantly increase Uber's capital expenditure, further increasing its already prodigious cash burn.  That being said, public markets can be irrational in the short to medium term, so it is entirely possible that Uber's IPO will succeed. Uber will likely not proceed with an IPO if valuations fall short of expectations - I doubt they will go forward unless they achieve a valuation higher than their last funding round of $72bn.  There are external factors to consider as well - if the current downturn were to accelerate, it is unlikely that Uber would IPO into a weak equity market.

Guassian principles applied to a 74 billion mean and 44.2 billion standard deviation. Then the fact that they are aiming to get it done by 2019 made me give them 3:1 odds of doing it. They need to do it by the first 3/4 of the year so I reduced by a factor of 3:4. Then they are aiming for the second half of the year so that reduces our range again, this time by 1:3. Finally, they are have incentive to beat Lyft, so I tacked on a 7:4 odds for that piece. Multiplying these odds I got 63:48. Or 57% chance of completion.

IPO is set some time next year. Uber Technologies Inc. filed paperwork confidentially this week for its initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter, as it races with smaller rival Lyft Inc. to be the first to market. The S-1 filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission puts Uber neck-and-neck with Lyft. Both planned IPOs are shaping up to be among the biggest in a spate of offerings aimed for 2019. Lyft said Thursday it had filed its S-1, and people familiar with the matter have said it is aiming to debut in March or April. Uber’s filing indicates it could go public as soon as the first quarter, as The Wall Street Journal reported in October. That would be sooner than many observers had expected. Uber Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi has said he expected to seek a debut in next year’s second half.

Pro:
1)	Good and convenient service for customers
2)	Growth of revenue
3)	Ready to public offering
4)	Good previous investors in Uber (before IPO)
5)	Uber needs IPO
Con:
1)	Problems in new projects of Uber (autonomous auto)
2)	Losses (but many companies had losses before IPO)
3)	Timing

Dateline `0-2-2018 According to a finance professor cited by the Wall Street Journal, 83 percent of U.S.-listed IPOs that took place during the first three quarters of this year “lost money in the 12 months leading up to their debut.” The Journal goes on to note that the previous record for the statistic was “when 81% of stock-market debutantes were unprofitable.” If you were looking another possible market top signal, there you are. ... The last time that public investors welcomed this many unprofitable companies things ended poorly. That may happen this time, or not. No one knows. But what is plain is that standards are down and losses are up. -- https://news.crunchbase.com/news/over-80-of-2018-ipos-are-unprofitable-setting-new-record/

I think Uber is in a rush to get this done before Lyft. It looks like valuations run ~$70 billion and that has been pretty consistent. I think there will be some IPO excitement, but there are a lot of problems with the company's balance sheet. So, I think it won't get near the optimistic $120 billion figure being floated. Typically, there are 50% discounts in this kind of scenario and given suggested evaluations by real investments being made, best guess is somewhere around the $70-$100 billion range. I'm going to take a slightly higher than default for the next bucket, and then slightly hedge from there. Lyft. Lyft is looking at a $15 billion IPO.[1]   Whoever goes first, will set expectations for the second company. Uber is currently valued at $72 billion by investors.[2]  "For the biggest private technology companies, valuation expectations can change drastically in the months leading up to a listing. Snap Inc.’s valuation was seen as being as high as $40 billion five months before its IPO last year, a person familiar said at the time. The company’s IPO ended up valuing it at about $20 billion. In June, Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi Corp. went public in Hong Kong at a $54 billion valuation after targeting $100 billion just months prior."[3] A year ago, Uber was valued at $50-70 billion by students using a the commonly used discounted cash flow valuation model.[4] [1] https://qz.com/1426102/lyft-hires-bankers-in-race-to-go-public-before-uber/
[2] https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/27/17787878/toyota-uber-investment-self-driving-car-research
[3] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-16/uber-is-said-to-get-ipo-pitches-at-potential-120-billion-value

FWIW, I've got no special insight into this one. My assumptions are:
1) If there is no recession, it is likely the IPO will go thru by 10/01.
2) If there is a recession, it will likely be put off until after 10/01.
3) If there is an IPO prior to 10/01, a (very) quick google search indicates an expected IPO of around $70B.
The Stock market is overdue for a recession in the 2019 time frame. The yield is inverting, the yeild is inverting. It isn't too soon to crack open skulls and feast on the goo inside!

Unlikely to trade above 3-4x EV/sales given increasing competition and cash burn.  Given multiple leadership/legal/ESG issues, as well as technology falling out of favor in the market recently, the IPO feels like a coin flip to begin with.
I believe that Uber will not have an IPO before 1 October 2019, but, if it does, it won't be stellar, due to the big gaps in the business model that are already a problem for its business model.
